results.title: Communication without speech
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, George Cass and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Recent advances in technology have enabled the development of a range of sophisticated communication devices which, with the assistance of microprocessors, enables students with severe communication impairment to communicate, using voice and print.

results.title: Afghanistan, Pushtun people: making felt
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Mountain peoples of Central Asia”.
Shows how women of the Pushtun tribe make felt mats for their families and for decorating the hard floor of their black camel-hair tents. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Building a bridge: Tajik
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mountain peoples of Central Asia”.
Shows how, in three days of actual construction, one hundred Tajik men and boys from one village work together to rebuild their hand-construction bridge. No narration.

results.title: Boys' game: Pushtu nomads
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mountain peoples of Central Asia”.
Shows an ancient game, well-known in Asia, being played by Pushtu boys. Demonstrates the toughness of the young men and the value these tribal people place on physical superiority. Suitable for upper primary and lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Russell Drysdale
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Five Australians”.
This film shows personal interviews between Russell Drysdale and Australian author George Johnston. Their discussions centre on Drysdale’s slowly developing portrait of Johnston and closely examine the values and lifestyle of what Sidney Nolan calls “the most Australian painter”. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Kanga Cricket
results.brief_description: An Australian Cricket Board primary development programme for kids, sponsored by the Australian Diary Corporation and supported by the Commonwealth Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Demonstrates the concept of Kanga cricket, a simplified adaptation of traditional cricket rules introduced into Australian schools. Former Australian cricket captain Kim Hughes and Peter Russell-Clarke participate.

results.title: In the beginning
results.brief_description: A colourful clay animation film which satirizes society and its impulse to invent nuclear weapons which cause self-destruction. Looks at the invention of destructive weapons from raspberries to rockets! Narration: Brian Woods. Animation: Mark D’Arcy-Irvine, Masfufah Sani. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: The Age of change
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Looks at the impact of technological change on the Melbourne newspaper ‘The Age’ and considers this change in terms of its effect on the people involved. Highlights the increasing competition at the desk of reporters and editors from electronic information systems, and the impact of technology on the once labour-intensive area of printing.

results.title: Rabbit Control [Part 1: Poisoning with 1080]
results.creator_credit: Ian Blythman, John Atkins and Conservation Forests and Lands
results.brief_description: This program narrated by Maurie Fields shows the problem of pest control in rural Victoria, and the adverse effects on farming if rabbit populations are not controlled. Part 1 explains the proper steps and procedure in using the poison 1080, the various safety precautions, equipment and supplies and tidy up details.

results.title: The Punter
results.brief_description: A short film about Jack Burnett and his involvment in the horse racing industry in the 1970s. (Jack is the father-in-law of the filmmaker) Identifiable with many students. Could be used for discussion on the idea of bought leisure and deals with gambling relating to horse racing.
